newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil's Malan dismisses trade, U.S. rate fears.
newsitem.headline: Brazil's Malan dismisses trade, U.S. rate fears.

text.p: Brazilian Finance Minister Pedro Malan Friday dismissed fears over the country's widening trade gap and said he was not concerned by a possible rate hike in the United States.
Malan told reporters the government had taken numerous measures to boost exports and the result would be felt over the coming months.
"The result will be felt over the next months, so we are not concerned with the results of our trade balance. We are betting on the months and years ahead," Malan said.
Brazil posted a $2.0 billion trade deficit for the first two months of 1997 after a record $5.54 billion gap last year.
The finance minister said hawkish inflation comments by U.S. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan were of no concern to Brazil.
He said speculation centered on a 0.25-0.50 percentage point rise in U.S. interest rates next week.

"The effect of this on our economy would be irrelevant," Malan said, saying investors' perception of Brazilian risk had fallen sufficiently for the economy to swallow a 0.25-0.50 percentage point hike in U.S. rates.
Malan also said the government did not currently see any reason to slam the brakes on consumption.
But he added, "If at any time we reach the conclusion that it would be desirable, we will not hesitate."
The widening trade gap and strong second half 1996 growth have led to speculation the government may try to ease demand by tightening credit or monetary policy.
